  <div class="admonition-title overview">
    <div class="label">
      <h3 id="KB_castelvetro_i">KB castelvetro</h3>
      <a class="individual" href="#KB_castelvetro_i">https://w3id.org/contro/data#KB_castelvetro</a>
    </div>
  <ul>
    <h4>Class</h4>
    <li>
      <a class="class" href="../arg/#KnowledgeBase_c" title="https://w3id.org/contro/arg#KnowledgeBase">Knowledge Base</a><span class="sup" data-text="c" title="Class"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>
  </div>
  </div>

<div class="admonition individual" markdown>
  <div class="admonition-title overview">
    <div class="label">
      <h3 id="latinisms_i">Latinisms</h3>
      <a class="individual" href="#latinisms_i">https://w3id.org/contro/data#latinisms</a>
    </div>
  </div>
  <p class="description">Lexical Latinisms are loanwords from written Latin that are artificially introduced into Italian through phonetic and morphological adaptation, as opposed to hereditary words, which result naturally from uninterrupted phonetic evolution. Latinisms are often employed in poetic texts to elevate the stylistic register.</p>
  </div>

<div class="admonition individual" markdown>
  <div class="admonition-title overview">
    <div class="label">
      <h3 id="castelvetro_i">Lodovico Castelvetro</h3>
      <a class="individual" href="#castelvetro_i">https://w3id.org/contro/data#castelvetro</a>
    </div>
  <ul>
    <h4>Class</h4>
    <li>
      <a class="class" href="http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/dul/DUL.owl#Agent" title="http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/dul/DUL.owl#Agent">Agent</a><span class="sup" data-text="c" title="Class"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>
  </div>
  </div>

<details class="individual" name="element" markdown>
  <summary>
  <div class="overview">
    <div class="label">
      <h3 id="r1_i">r1</h3>
      <a class="individual" href="#r1_i">https://w3id.org/contro/data#r1</a>
    </div>
  </div>
  <p class="description">The fact that Petrarch left out words used in the literature of his time is a sign that he did not use them deliberately.</p>
  </summary>
  <div class="extra">
    <ul>
      <h4>Assertions</h4>
      <li>
        <a class="object_property" href="../arg/#Antecedent_op" title="https://w3id.org/contro/arg#Antecedent">Antecedent</a><span class="sup" data-text="op" title="Object Property"></span> <a class="individual" href="#s1_i" title="https://w3id.org/contro/data#s1">s1</a><span class="sup" data-text="i" title="Individual"></span>
      </li>
      <li>

    </div>
  </div>
  <p class="description">Literary imitation should emulate the author’s judgment, not reproduce their words.</p>
  </summary>
  <div class="extra">
    <ul>
      <h4>Assertions</h4>
      <li>
        <a class="object_property" href="../arg/#contradicts_op" title="https://w3id.org/contro/arg#contradicts">contradicts</a><span class="sup" data-text="op" title="Object Property"></span> <a class="individual" href="#r2_i" title="https://w3id.org/contro/data#r2">r2</a><span class="sup" data-text="i" title="Individual"></span>
      </li>
      <li>
        <a class="data_property" href="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value" title="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value">value</a><span class="sup" data-text="dp" title="Data Property"></span> To imitate him means to carry oneself and move one’s legs as he did, not to place one’s feet in his very footprints. He made judicious use, in all languages, of all worthy words; with the same judgment, anyone may likewise make use of them.
      </li>
    </ul>
  </div>
</details>

<details class="individual" name="element" markdown>
  <summary>
  <div class="overview">
    <div class="label">
      <h3 id="s19_i">s19</h3>
      <a class="individual" href="#s19_i">https://w3id.org/contro/data#s19</a>
    </div>
  </div>
  <p class="description">To limit authors’ ability to interpret and develop the language by binding it to past usage is akin to denying the contemporary Church its role in interpreting and expanding upon sacred Scripture.</p>
  </summary>
  <div class="extra">
    <ul>
      <h4>Assertions</h4>
      <li>
        <a class="data_property" href="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value" title="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value">value</a><span class="sup" data-text="dp" title="Data Property"></span> This is to hold in matters of language the very same belief one holds in matters of faith: to claim that vernacular Italian should be confined to Petrarch and Boccaccio, just as to claim that sacred Scripture is wholly contained in the Gospels and Saint Paul.
      </li>
    </ul>
  </div>
</details>

<details class="individual" name="element" markdown>
  <summary>
  <div class="overview">
    <div class="label">
      <h3 id="s2_i">s2</h3>
      <a class="individual" href="#s2_i">https://w3id.org/contro/data#s2</a>
    </div>
  </div>
  <p class="description">Other authors of his time used those words.</p>
  </summary>
  <div class="extra">
    <ul>
      <h4>Assertions</h4>
      <li>
        <a class="data_property" href="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value" title="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value">value</a><span class="sup" data-text="dp" title="Data Property"></span> since they had perhaps all, or at least most, been used by writers of his time
      </li>
    </ul>
  </div>
</details>

<div class="admonition individual" markdown>
  <div class="admonition-title overview">
    <div class="label">
      <h3 id="s20_i">s20</h3>
      <a class="individual" href="#s20_i">https://w3id.org/contro/data#s20</a>
    </div>
  </div>
  <p class="description">The Church holds the autority to interpret and expand upon sacred Scripture.</p>
  </div>

<details class="individual" name="element" markdown>
  <summary>
  <div class="overview">
    <div class="label">
      <h3 id="s21_i">s21</h3>
      <a class="individual" href="#s21_i">https://w3id.org/contro/data#s21</a>
    </div>
  </div>
  <p class="description">Contemporary authors have the freedom to interpret and develop the language.</p>
  </summary>
  <div class="extra">
    <ul>
      <h4>Assertions</h4>
      <li>
        <a class="data_property" href="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value" title="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value">value</a><span class="sup" data-text="dp" title="Data Property"></span> Nor do I wish to be deprived of the freedom they themselves enjoyed, as did all writers in every language.
      </li>
    </ul>
  </div>
</details>

<details class="individual" name="element" markdown>
  <summary>
  <div class="overview">
    <div class="label">
      <h3 id="s22_i">s22</h3>
      <a class="individual" href="#s22_i">https://w3id.org/contro/data#s22</a>
    </div>
  </div>
  <p class="description">Petrarch exercised authorial freedom in shaping the language.</p>
  </summary>
  <div class="extra">
    <ul>
      <h4>Assertions</h4>
      <li>
        <a class="data_property" href="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value" title="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value">value</a><span class="sup" data-text="dp" title="Data Property"></span> Beyond this, that Petrarch has taken away from others what he himself did?
      </li>
    </ul>
  </div>
</details>

<details class="individual" name="element" markdown>
  <summary>
  <div class="overview">
    <div class="label">
      <h3 id="s23_i">s23</h3>
      <a class="individual" href="#s23_i">https://w3id.org/contro/data#s23</a>
    </div>
  </div>
  <p class="description">In dead languages like Latin and Greek, one must imitate the best authors.</p>
  </summary>
  <div class="extra">
    <ul>
      <h4>Assertions</h4>
      <li>
        <a class="data_property" href="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value" title="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value">value</a><span class="sup" data-text="dp" title="Data Property"></span> For here lies the error you have fallen into: believing that in this language one ought to act as in Greek and Latin—languages which, being dead as regards common speech, must necessarily be written by drawing from the writings of the few and by imitating the best, since we cannot ourselves grasp their native power or beauty.
      </li>
    </ul>
  </div>
</details>

<details class="individual" name="element" markdown>
  <summary>
  <div class="overview">
    <div class="label">
      <h3 id="s24_i">s24</h3>
      <a class="individual" href="#s24_i">https://w3id.org/contro/data#s24</a>
    </div>
  </div>
  <p class="description">Italian is a living language.</p>
  </summary>
  <div class="extra">
    <ul>
      <h4>Assertions</h4>
      <li>
        <a class="data_property" href="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value" title="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value">value</a><span class="sup" data-text="dp" title="Data Property"></span> But in this language—which is naturally and commonly spoken and understood by all, and which presents itself to us alive and entirely uncovered in all its parts—
      </li>
    </ul>
  </div>
</details>

<details class="individual" name="element" markdown>
  <summary>
  <div class="overview">
    <div class="label">
      <h3 id="s25_i">s25</h3>
      <a class="individual" href="#s25_i">https://w3id.org/contro/data#s25</a>
    </div>
  </div>
  <p class="description">Italian should not be limited to the authority of a single author, such as Petrarch.</p>
  </summary>
  <div class="extra">
    <ul>
      <h4>Assertions</h4>
      <li>
        <a class="data_property" href="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value" title="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value">value</a><span class="sup" data-text="dp" title="Data Property"></span> what kind of judgment is it to think that one must necessarily draw from the writings of a single author, and not also from the many who speak and write it;
      </li>
    </ul>
  </div>
</details>

<details class="individual" name="element" markdown>
  <summary>
  <div class="overview">
    <div class="label">
      <h3 id="s3_i">s3</h3>
      <a class="individual" href="#s3_i">https://w3id.org/contro/data#s3</a>
    </div>
  </div>
  <p class="description">Petrarch wouldn’t have used those words.</p>
  </summary>
  <div class="extra">
    <ul>
      <h4>Assertions</h4>
      <li>
        <a class="data_property" href="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value" title="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value">value</a><span class="sup" data-text="dp" title="Data Property"></span> Petrarch would not have used any of the elements he noted in Caro’s canzone
      </li>
      <li>
        <a class="data_property" href="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value" title="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value">value</a><span class="sup" data-text="dp" title="Data Property"></span> Petrarch would not use:
      </li>
      <li>
        <a class="data_property" href="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value" title="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value">value</a><span class="sup" data-text="dp" title="Data Property"></span> that Petrarch would not use cede and the other words that follow
      </li>
    </ul>
  </div>
</details>

<details class="individual" name="element" markdown>
  <summary>
  <div class="overview">
    <div class="label">
      <h3 id="s4_i">s4</h3>
      <a class="individual" href="#s4_i">https://w3id.org/contro/data#s4</a>
    </div>
  </div>
  <p class="description">Petrarch is an authority in Italian literature.</p>
  </summary>
  <div class="extra">
    <ul>
      <h4>Assertions</h4>
      <li>
        <a class="data_property" href="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value" title="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value">value</a><span class="sup" data-text="dp" title="Data Property"></span> I grant that the perfection of style—though never fully realized in practice—has, up to now, been found in our language particularly in Petrarch and Boccaccio.
      </li>
      <li>
        <a class="data_property" href="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value" title="http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#value">value</a><span class="sup" data-text="dp" title="Data Property"></span> since he holds Petrarch as the prince of poets in our language, worthy of reverence and admiration above all others.
      </li>
    </ul>
  </div>
</details>
